value: *This file takes the original 1980 data and creates three datasets: one for wives (with husbands vars matched and child vars added), one for single women (with child vars added) and one for single men
*Create subfamily ID var (consistent with CPS definition)
*CHECK ALL OF THIS
/* & momid~=pernum*/
*replace subfamunit=momid2 if subfamunit==. & momid==pernum
/*& popid~=pernum*/
*NOTE THE AGE RESTRICTION IN THIS: 18-65
*ALSO I AM CURRENTLY COUNTING CHILDREN AS LONG AS THEY ARE NOT MARRIED WITH SPOUSE PRESENT OR ABSENT
*The following creates a matched wife-husband dataset (Census 1980 Wife data.dta)
*The next two lines create a var that allocates children to their mother or their father if she isn't present
*The next section creates a temporary dataset (full child) containing the number of male children at each age up to 18 and 19plus, excluding children who are married
*The child's mother's line number might be up to 26, hence the next line
*Next line added to save space
*The next section adds the number of female children at each age level to the temporary dataset
*Next line added to save space
*The next section merges in the number of children to their fathers (only those children who don't have a mother in the household)
*The next section merges in the number of children to their mothers and then merges in the fathers' child data
*merge year serial sploc using "$path\Census 1980 Husb data"
*keep if _merge==3
*drop _merge
*The next section adds the mothers' and fathers' child data at each sex/age level
****drop if p_stat==2|spp_stat==2
****drop if h_type==9
*The following creates a dataset for single men (with no child data)
*The following creates a dataset for single women
*Once again, the next section creates the child data for each mother and merges the files into the mothers' dataset
*Next line added to save space
*Next line added to save space
